reviews.text: The staff in this hotel were very helpful but the condition of our room was poor. The whole place smelt damp and musty. Our room decor was very tired and old. It was the worst place we stayed in during a two week trip. The annex looked much better.
reviews.title: Did not like
Solitude at the Turtle Inn
reviews.text: The Turtle Inn reflected the quiet and serenity of Nikko with quiet rooms, lounge areas, and spas for single or "family" use. Internet access was provided for those that can't unplug (or just want to check the weather). My wife & I stayed one night in Nikko - which was sufficient during late winter/spring conditions. We didn't get a meal at the Hotel but maybe should have, since we stayed in Nikko on a Thursday on March 31st and all the restaurants seemed to be closed except for the Asian Garden by the Train Station (a bus ride away). The hotel, located adjacent the Daiyagawa river is walking distance to the major shrines. Across a bridge past the Turtle Inn Annex is a park with approximately 100 stone Buddhas (each with red cap). Our room cost was 9,000 Yen for one night, the room had a sink, and use of shared bathrooms. If returning to Nikko, I would stay at the Turtle Inn again.

Arrived late in Nikko and needed somewhere to stay. Would not recommend this place at all. The room was damp, cold and the bathroom was absolutely tiny. There are other more comfortable places to stay in Nikko.
reviews.title: Awful

reviews.text: The good: Friendly staff, who spoke enough English to get by. Convenient location. Because we were there on a Sunday, there was no dinner available. Breakfast was fine -- coffee, fruit, bread. Overpriced but, given the limited food options around, probably worth doing.
reviews.title: Just recovering

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The bad: The rooms, however, were dreadful. Minor complaint about the teeny bathroom, but that's not a big deal. The mold, however, in both of our rooms, was overpowering. Covering patches on the wall, ceiling, and seams in the bathroom. My daughter and I had headaches and upper respiratory stuff that is now fading, two days after we left. Can't open the windows -- big holes in the screens let in the many bugs attracted to the light. If you have choices, I would avoid this.
reviews.title: Great Nikko Bargain!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We just spent three days at the Turtle Inn in Nikko and were very impressed. For the price, it's one of the best accommodation bargains we've seen in Japan. For less than 10,000 yen per night, we had a small but clean room with en suite Western bath and two very comfortable Western beds, plus unlimited use of the inn's hot baths. While not a true onsen (natural hot springs inn), the Turtle pipes its hot bath water directly from a natural hot spring just upstream of the inn. It has two baths, one perfect for two, and another just right for solo soaking. As we were there in December, just after the Fall color tourist season, we had the place almost to ourselves. The friendly proprietors speak English and will provide reasonably priced breakfast (fresh fruit, juice, eggs, breads) and dinner (trout and sukiyaki) if you order them the day before. Nikko has some of the most visually spectacular temples and shrines within an easy walk of the inn. A 5- minute walk will take you to the stop for frequent bus service to the JR station and nearby Lake Chuzenji and Kegon waterfall. The Inn offers both Western and Japanese-style rooms. While the Turtle Inn is not a luxury accommodation, it is convenient, clean, comfortable and a real bargain in a beautiful town.
reviews.title: Dreadful room

reviews.text: It rains a lot in Nikko - we slept with the window open in the cold November night air because the damp and mildew smell was overpowering. Unlike the other guest comments, I didn't see the damp - but you could sure smell it. The room was damp, tiny, tatty and overpriced. The meals were good - but they just couldn't make up for the poor accomodation. A real disappointment. The worst place I stayed in Japan in over three weeks.
